EzPyGame¶

Easier and more pythonic usage of pygame.

class ezpygame.Application(title='EzPyGame App', resolution=(640, 480), update_rate=30)[source]¶

The class for creating a pygame application.

A simple wrapper around pygame, which initializes and quits pygame as the application starts/ends. Also makes the scene management seamless and fun together with Scene.

Example usage:

class Menu(ezpygame.Scene):
    ...

class Game(ezpygame.Scene):
    ...

app = ezpygame.Application(
    title='My First EzPyGame Application',
    resolution=(1280, 720),
    update_rate=60,
)
main_menu = Menu()
app.run(main_menu)
__init__(title='EzPyGame App', resolution=(640, 480), update_rate=30)[source]¶

Initialize the application with window settings.

Parameters:
  • title (str) – title to display in the window’s title bar
  • resolution (tuple[int,int]) – resolution of the game window
  • update_rate (int) – how many times per second to update
active_scene¶

The currently active scene.

change_scene(scene)[source]¶

Change the currently active scene in the application.

This will change the current scene and invoke Scene.on_exit() and Scene.on_enter() on the switching scenes (unless None).

The scene will change after the next update.

Parameters:scene (Scene) – the scene to change into
resolution¶

The application’s game window’s resolution.

run(scene=None)[source]¶

Run the application.

Parameters:scene (Scene) – initial scene to start the execution from
title¶

The title to display in the application’s game window.

class ezpygame.Scene[source]¶

An individual scene in the application.

Create a scene by subclassing and overriding any of the methods.

Example usage with two scenes interacting:

class Menu(Scene):

    def __init__(self):
        self.font = pygame.font.Font(...)

    def on_enter(self, previous_scene):
        self.application.title = 'Main Menu',
        self.application.update_rate = 30

    def draw(self, screen):
        pygame.draw.rect(...)
        text = self.font.render(...)
        screen.blit(text, ...)

    def handle_event(self, event):
        if event.type == pygame.MOUSEBUTTONUP:
            if event.button == 1:
                game_size = self._get_game_size(event.pos)
                self.change_scene(Game(game_size))

    def _get_game_size(self, mouse_pos_upon_click):
        ...
